slides.title: Studying 2
slides.subtitle: Practical techniques to learn — not just review
bullets: Make your study sessions produce real memory and skill

slides.title: The Problem
bullets: Most people 'study,' but don’t learn.
Re-reading notes feels productive, but it doesn’t stick.
Highlighting makes you familiar, not fluent.
Real learning happens when your brain has to retrieve and apply.
slides.note: If studying feels easy, it’s probably not working.

slides.title: The 3 Rules of Effective Study
bullets: Active recall: force your brain to pull information out.
Spaced repetition: revisit over time, not in one big block.
Deliberate practice: target what you get wrong, not what you already know.
slides.note: These three are the difference between 'I saw it' and 'I can do it.'

slides.title: Active Recall — What to Do
bullets: Blurting: close notes → write everything you remember → check gaps.
Practice questions: use exam-style problems, not summaries.
Teach-back: explain the concept as if tutoring someone.
timedSteps: Quick example: Instead of 'read the chapter,' do: 'Answer 10 questions, then mark and fix errors.'

slides.title: Spacing & Interleaving — How to Schedule
bullets: Spacing: shorter sessions over multiple days beats cramming.
Schedule: Day 0: learn • Day 1: recall • Day 3: recall again • Day 7: mixed practice.
Interleaving: mix topics — don’t grind one topic for hours.
It feels harder in the moment — that difficulty means it’s working better.

slides.title: The Feedback Loop — How to Improve Fast
bullets: After every session ask: What did I get wrong? Why?
Identify repeating patterns: they are your study plan.
Rule: Spend ~70% of time on weak areas, 30% on review.

slides.title: A Simple 45-Min Study Template
timedSteps: 25–35 min: mark answers and log errors.
35–45 min: re-attempt wrong questions + schedule next review.
slides.note: No fancy motivation needed—just a system.

slides.title: Closing
bullets: Effective studying isn’t about time. It’s about technique.
If you make only one change: swap re-reading for retrieval (practice questions + recall), then space it out.
